questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the physician because of increasing forgetfulness, unsteadiness, and falls over the past year. He reports that these symptoms seem to worsen with each fall. Initially, he could not remember directions to his home but now cannot remember recent conversations or appointments he has made. He often repeats questions that he asked shortly before. He has long-standing hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include aspirin, carvedilol, enalapril, and atorvastatin. Examination shows a bruise over the left temple and an unsteady gait. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person and place only. Short-term memory is impaired; he can recall 0 out of 5 objects after 10 minutes. Long-term memory is intact. He has no delusions or hallucinations. Muscle strength is decreased in the left lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the left. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is an anticoagulant that can be used to prevent thromboembolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Vascular dementia, however, is primarily a small vessel disease caused by lipohyalinosis or microatheroma formation, not thromboemboli, and is primarily treated with antiplatelet agents rather than anticoagulants. Anticoagulants may be indicated in some patients with vascular dementia who have previously had a cardioembolic stroke, but neither the imaging findings in this patient nor his history point towards a previous cardioembolic stroke. Therefore, anticoagulation is not indicated in this patient. In addition, because this patient has a very high fall risk (unsteady gait with decreased muscle strength in the lower extremities and a bruise over the left temple), anticoagulants should be avoided if possible.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin E is an antioxidant that has been studied as a possible treatment for Alzheimer disease (AD), which can manifest with short-term memory loss and spatial disorientation. However, CT findings typically seen in AD include ventriculomegaly, narrowing of gyri, and prominent cerebral sulci with disproportionate atrophy of the hippocampi. Although there are no adverse effects associated with vitamin E therapy, it has not been shown to improve cognition secondary to vascular dementia.

C) INCORRECT:

Cerebral shunt placement is an important step in the treatment of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), which commonly causes dementia and an unsteady gait. However, NPH also manifests with urinary incontinence and ventriculomegaly on neuroimaging. This patient's head CT scan shows ventricles of normal size, which rules out NPH.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

D) INCORRECT:

Tetrabenazine is a medication used in the treatment of chorea associated with Huntington disease (HD), which may cause cognitive-behavioral changes and symptoms of dementia (e.g., memory loss, spatial disorientation) in advanced stages. Although a head CT scan may show cerebral atrophy in HD, these changes are most pronounced in the caudate. In addition, this patient has an ataxic gait (an atypical finding in HD) and no history of chorea.

E) CORRECT:

Cognitive training is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's confirmed vascular dementia. While cognitive training and rehabilitation are important components of treatment for all forms of dementia, treatment specific to vascular dementia also includes reduction of cardiovascular risk factors and, in some cases, anticoagulation. However, this patient's medical regimen for his cardiovascular conditions is already optimal and he cannot be started on anticoagulation because he is at high risk of falling.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Abnormal low attenuation areas (green overlay) are seen in the periventricular white matter. Two frontal lacunar infarcts (arrowheads) are also present.

These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.
questions.hint: Progressive impairment in an individual with cardiovascular disease, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and focal neurologic deficits in conjunction with a head CT scan showing hypodense periventricular lesions is highly suggestive of vascular dementia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for forgetfulness, confusion, and mood changes for the past 4 months. His symptoms started with misplacing items such as his wallet and keys around the house. Two months ago, he became unable to manage their finances as it became too difficult for him. Last week, he became lost while returning home from the grocery store. His wife reports that he shows “no emotion” and that he is seemingly not concerned by his recent symptoms. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, metformin, and rosuvastatin. His pulse is 56/min and blood pressure is 158/76 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows loss of sensation on his right leg and an unsteady gait. When asked to stand with his eyes closed and palms facing upward, his right arm rotates inward. An MRI of the brain shows multiple deep white matter lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation with a relatively abrupt cognitive decline and a stepwise deterioration in function (from misplacing items to being unable to manage finances to becoming lost in a familiar place) is suggestive of vascular dementia (i.e., multi-infarct dementia). The primary pathogenesis of this disease is atherosclerosis, for which diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and uncontrolled hypertension are risk factors. The diagnosis is further supported by the presence of neurologic deficits on examination, such as right-sided pronator drift, numbness in the right leg, and unsteady gait. The multiple deep white matter lesions on cranial MRI represent previous lacunar infarcts.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Abnormal low attenuation zones are seen in the periventricular white matter adjacent to the frontal and temporal horns of the lateral ventricles (green overlay). The cerebral sulci (examples indicated by red overlay) and ventricles are also prominent.

These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.

B) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia is associated with personality changes (e.g., apathy) and eventual decline in cognitive function. Physical examination may show pyramidal signs such as a pronator drift. However, cranial MRI is more likely to show atrophy of the frontal and/or temporal lobes than white matter lesions. Other features of frontotemporal dementia include disinhibition, loss of empathy, binge eating, and exaggerated emotional display.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)

There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).

As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.

Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's cognitive decline and apathy are possible features of Alzheimer disease, which is the most common cause of dementia in older adults. However, Alzheimer disease typically has a more insidious onset and slow progression with early memory loss rather than a rapid stepwise deterioration in executive function. Moreover, Alzheimer disease is unlikely to manifest with neurologic deficits on physical examination (e.g., pronator drift, numbness, abnormal gait) and MRI would show cerebral atrophy rather than white matter lesions.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbance

There is bilateral cerebral atrophy, with prominent sulci (green overlay).

Multiple small hyperintense foci in the white matter (examples outlined) are enlarged perivascular spaces (Virchow-Robin spaces).

D) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder is the most common cause of pseudodementia, for which this patient's age is a risk factor. Apathy is a feature of major depressive disorder; however, this patient does not meet the clinical criteria for depression. Moreover, pseudodementia is unlikely to present with neurologic deficits on physical examination (e.g., pronator drift, numbness, abnormal gait) and is not associated with white matter lesions on cranial MRI.

E) INCORRECT:

Lewy body dementia causes a variable sequence of symptoms that may include forgetfulness, confusion, and unsteady gait. However, physical examination would more likely show extrapyramidal motor symptoms (e.g., bradykinesia) than focal neurologic deficits (e.g., numbness, pronator drift). Other common features of Lewy body dementia not present in this patient include visual hallucinations and rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder. A cranial MRI would show regional cerebral atrophy rather than white matter lesions.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient's mood changes, forgetfulness, and bradycardia are possible features of hypothyroidism. However, this condition is not associated with focal neurologic deficits (e.g., numbness, pronator drift, abnormal gait). Other common features of hypothyroidism include fatigue, cold intolerance, skin and hair changes, weight gain, and constipation. This patient's bradycardia can be explained by metoprolol use and his mood changes and forgetfulness are more likely due to the abnormalities seen in his MRI.

G) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause a variety of neuropsychiatric symptoms, including apathy, forgetfulness, numbness, and unsteady gait. However, neuropathy would more likely be symmetrical and abnormal cranial MRI findings would be unlikely. Moreover, vitamin B12 deficiency typically manifests with signs of anemia (e.g., fatigue, pallor), scleral icterus, or glossitis.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical history (stepwise decline in executive function), physical examination (presence of focal neurologic deficits), and MRI findings (multiple deep white matter lesions) are suggestive of the second most common type of dementia in older individuals.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia is brought to the clinic by her daughter. The daughter reports that since last seeing her mother one year ago, her mother is slower to accomplish things around the house, lacks initiative, and walks more slowly. The patient reports no feelings of depression, recent illnesses, or hallucinations. Her blood pressure was suboptimally controlled in the past, but she has been more adherent to her medications recently.
She scores 24 out of 30 on the Folstein Mini-Mental Status Examination, indicating mild cognitive impairment. She lost points for calculation and orientation but had intact registration, immediate memory, delayed recall, and visuospatial construction. The rest of her neurologic examination is normal, except for a reduced gait speed.
Laboratory evaluation reveals normal vitamin B12 and thyroid-stimulating hormone levels and a negative treponemal antibody test.
MRI of the brain reveals extensive confluent periventricular and temporal lobe white-matter hyperintensities (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The diagnosis of vascular cognitive impairment can be established by demonstrating cognitive impairment along with either a history of clinical stroke or imaging that reveals features of cerebrovascular disease, such as diffuse periventricular white-matter intensities.

Periventricular white-matter hyperintensities have been most closely associated with vascular causes of dementia and predict an increased risk for stroke, cerebrovascular events, dementia, and death.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of hypertension who demonstrates a gradual loss of cognitive function and whose MRI is found to have extensive confluent periventricular and temporal lobe white-matter hyperintensities is vascular cognitive impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with normal-pressure hydrocephalus usually have ventriculomegaly out of proportion to cortical atrophy on MRI.

C) INCORRECT:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease typically causes rapidly progressive dementia with global cognitive impairment that may be accompanied by gait abnormalities and stimulus-induced myoclonus. Many patients have cortical and basal ganglia abnormalities on diffusion-weighted MRI sequences.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients who have dementia with Lewy bodies usually exhibit fluctuations in cognition, accompanied by visual hallucinations, and signs of parkinsonism on examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Although Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of dementia, vascular dementia is also quite common. Patients with Alzheimer disease usually have more memory impairment as the presenting feature, whereas patients with vascular dementia usually have greater impairment with executive functioning.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a past medical history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease is brought to the office by his wife for forgetfulness and confusion for the past 4 months. His symptoms started with misplacing items around the house. Two months ago, he became unable to manage their finances as it became too difficult for him. Last week, he became lost while returning home from the grocery store. His wife reports that he is seemingly not concerned by his recent symptoms. Neurologic examination shows loss of sensation on his right leg and an unsteady gait. When asked to stand with his eyes closed and palms facing upward, his right arm rotates inward.
